publisher.publisher-name: The British Editorial Society of Bone & Joint Surgery

title-group.article-title: IMPACT-Scot report on COVID-19 and hip fracture

fn.label: Take home message
fn.p: · COVID-19 was independently associated with an increased 30 day mortality rate for patients with hip fracture.
· Most patients with a hip fracture and COVID-19 did not present with suggestive symptoms at presentation.
· Patterns of infection and models predictive of COVID-19 status are key topics for further research.

license.license-p: Open Access This article is distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial-No Derivatives 4.0 (CC BY-NC-ND 4.0) licence (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/), which permits the copying and redistribution of the work only, and provided the original author and source are credited.

abstract.title: Abstract
Aims
abstract.p: The primary aim was to assess the independent influence of COVID-19 on 30 day mortality for patients with hip fracture. The secondary aims were to determine whether: 1) there were clinical predictors of COVID-19 status; and 2) whether social lockdown influenced the incidence and epidemiology of hip fractures.
abstract.title: Methods
abstract.p: A national multicentre retrospective study was conducted of all patients presenting to six trauma centres or units with a hip fracture over a 46 day period (23 days pre- and 23 days post-lockdown). Patient demographics, type of residence, place of injury, presentation blood tests, Nottingham Hip Fracture Score, time to surgery, operation, American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) grade, anaesthetic, length of stay, COVID-19 status, and 30 day mortality were recorded.
abstract.title: Results
abstract.p: Of 317 patients with acute hip fracture, 27 (8.5%) had a positive COVID-19 test. Only seven (26%) had suggestive symptoms on admission. COVID-19 positive patients had a significantly lower 30 day survival compared to those without COVID-19 (64.5%, 95% confidence interval (CI) 45.7 to 83.3 vs 91.7%, 95% CI 88.2 to 94.8; p < 0.001). COVID-19 was independently associated with increased 30 day mortality risk adjusting for: 1) age, sex, type of residence (hazard ratio (HR) 2.93; p = 0.008); 2) Nottingham Hip Fracture Score (HR 3.52; p = 0.001); and 3) ASA (HR 3.45; p = 0.004). Presentation platelet count predicted subsequent COVID-19 status; a value of < 217 × 109/l was associated with 68% area under the curve (95% CI 58 to 77; p = 0.002) and a sensitivity and specificity of 63%. A similar number of patients presented with hip fracture in the 23 days pre-lockdown (n = 160) and 23 days post-lockdown (n = 157); there was no significant (all p ≥ 0.130) difference in patient demographics, residence, place of injury, Nottingham Hip Fracture Score, time to surgery, ASA or management.
abstract.title: Conclusion
abstract.p: COVID-19 was independently associated with an increased 30 day mortality rate for patients with hip fracture. Notably, most patients with hip fracture and COVID-19 lacked suggestive symptoms at presentation. Platelet count was an indicator of risk of COVID-19 infection. These findings have implications for the management of hip fracture, in particular the need for COVID-19 testing.

funding-group.funding-statement: No benefits in any form have been received or will be received from a commercial party related directly or indirectly to the subject of this article.

body.title: Introduction
body.p: The COVID-19 pandemic has transformed orthopaedic services with cessation of elective operating and a reduction in orthopaedic trauma operating capacity.1,2 This has been associated with a widespread reduction in population activity (work, travel, and recreation) and the enforcement of public health messages to stay home. The epidemiology of orthopaedic trauma demonstrates a reduction in major trauma and activity-related trauma, but the incidence of fragility fractures is unchanged.3,4 The specific impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on hip fracture patients is not clear, but it appears that such patients continue to present at a similar rate to orthopaedic trauma services and should be prioritized.3,4 Hip fracture patients are typically older and have high rates of frailty and comorbidities. Importantly, COVID-2019 mortality rates are higher in people with comorbidities,5 so hip fracture patients are as a population at high risk of poor outcomes from COVID-19. Care pathways may need to be modified to try and optimize outcomes.6

There is a paucity of data relating to the effect of COVID-19 on the mortality of patients with a hip fracture. A report from Spain that included 136 patients with a hip fracture demonstrated the unadjusted mortality rate was 10% at a mean follow-up of ten days, which increased to 30% at a mean of 14 days in 23 patients they identified as COVID-19-positive.7 However, these mortality rates were not adjusted for age, sex, place of residence, or other factors associated with early patient mortality after a hip fracture.8 Therefore, the true independent effect of COVID-19 on the mortality rate of patientsss with a hip fracture is not clear.

It is essential to avoid cross-infection of COVID-19 in patients presenting with a hip fracture and future patient pathways may need to be amended to account for this.6 If there were factors associated with a late diagnosis of COVID-19 in patients presenting with a hip fracture, this would help risk-stratify patients and aid care pathways to minimize the risk of cross-infection, which might in turn reduce the mortality risk in such a frail patient group. In addition, the effect of social lockdown on the epidemiology and standards of care of hip fracture patients has not been reported, to the authors’ knowledge, and this may be important to enable the planning of services in future pandemics.

This study reports the early findings of International Multicentre Project Auditing COVID-19 in Trauma & Orthopaedics (IMPACT) from Scottish centres contributing data to the collaborative.9 The primary aim of this study was to assess the independent influence of a positive diagnosis of COVID-19 on 30 day mortality for patients with a hip fracture. The secondary aims were to assess whether there were clinical predictors at the time of presentation associated with having or developing COVID-19, and whether social lockdown influenced the epidemiology of hip fracture patients and the standard of care.
body.title: Methods
body.p: In March 2020, data collection for the Scottish Hip Fracture Audit (SHFA)10 was suspended due to the disruption caused by the COVID-19 viral pandemic to the Local Audit Coordinator (LAC) infrastructure. A multicentre emergency clinical audit response was initiated and supported by the SHFA, Scottish Government, and the Scottish Committee for Orthopaedics & Trauma (SCOT) in response to the need for urgent clinical audit into COVID-19 and hip fractures. The IMPACT network was activated in all Scottish centres that provide acute hip fracture services. A multicentre observational study was conducted of data collected retrospectively from six Scottish hospitals, including two major trauma centres and four district general hospitals (DGHs), providing acute orthopaedic trauma management of patients with hip fractures. These six centres were identified as being able to collect reliable data promptly as part of the existing audit activity of LAC or orthopaedic surgeons. Data were collected in accordance with UK Caldicott principles11 and local data governance guidance, and no patient-identifiable data were transferred out with the local units or accessed by the central IMPACT research team.
body.title: Inclusion and exclusion criteria
body.p: All patients with a hip fracture who were aged 50 years and over and admitted to any of the six participating hospitals over the study period (1 March to 15 April 2020) were included. This interval was chosen in order to capture the period from the first recorded COVID-19 case in Scotland (1 March), spanning the introduction of social distancing measures and the enforced UK ‘lockdown’ on 23 March 2020 (first 23 days), and continuing to the time at which confirmed COVID-19 cases in Scotland reached their highest point in mid-April 2020 (23 days after lockdown). The same lockdown guidelines and restrictions were in place for Scotland as for the rest of the UK during the study period. We employed the same inclusion criteria as the SHFA, which was to include all intracapsular and extracapsular fractures involving the proximal femur up until the distal limit of the subtrochanteric region (defined as being 5 cm distal to the lesser trochanter). As per the SHFA criteria, isolated fractures of the acetabulum, pubic ramus, greater(Table I) trochanter, and periprosthetic fractures were excluded. During the study period 317 patients presented to the six study centres with a hip fracture. There were 211 (67%) female and 106 (33%) male patients with a mean age of 80 years (50 to 101) (Table ITables I and I).

body.title: Baseline data collection

list-item.p: A priori questions were developed before the collection of data, which was achieved through retrospective examination of local admission lists that were cross-referenced with patient medical records, trauma operating lists, and discharge letters. Data were collected using a bespoke digital IMPACT Hip Fracture Audit data collection tool comprising data-validated fields to ensure accuracy and consistency of coding, thus increasing intra- and interobserver reliability. Additionally, data collectors were provided with an IMPACT Hip Fracture Audit user guide and had continuous access for queries to the audit designer (AH).

body.p: Demographics, injury, and surgical data were collected and included: age; sex; pre-fracture residence; date of injury; location where the injury was sustained; date of admission; date of surgery; procedure type; surgical delay status (defined as being surgery out with 36 hours of diagnosis); non-operativenonoperative management; and anaesthetic type.

Data pertaining to clinical status and comorbidity were collected and included: American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) classification,10 presence or absence of each of six major comorbidity groups (cardiovascular disease, renal disease, pulmonary disease, dementia, acute neoplastic disease, and diabetes mellitus), and admission laboratory blood test results (haemoglobin, lymphocyte count, platelet count, serum sodium, and serum albumin). A Nottingham Hip Fracture Score was calculated for each patient.8,12 The laboratory blood tests were chosen as they had been demonstrated to correlate with disease severity or outcomes in hip fracture patients or development of COVID-19.13-17 Data were collected for COVID-19 status in the preoperative and postoperative periods separately. These included data pertaining to the presence or absence of symptoms or signs as being suggestive of COVID-19 (defined by the World Health Organization18 or features associated with COVID-19 in the frail population19) from inpatient medical records, laboratory swab requests, and discharge summaries. The results of SARS-CoV-2 RNA polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing was collected from local microbiology laboratory databases and was used to determine COVID-19 status: positive or negative. Swabs were obtained via the standard oropharyngeal and nasopharyngeal swab technique as part of the patients’ clinical management.inpatient
body.title: Outcome data collectioninpatient inpatient inpatient
body.p: Data relevant to early outcome measures were collected: date and destination of discharge from acute admission (defined as being the acute orthopaedic admission, or the total acute hospital admission if a patient was transferred from an acute orthopaedic unit to another acute unit of comparable care level); date of death, and death occurring during the acute admission. Patients were followed up for a minimum of 30 days.

Statistical analysis was performed using Statistical Product and Service Solutions version 17.0 (SPSS Statistics for Windows, Version 17.0; SPSS, Chicago, Illinois, USA). Parametric and non-parametric tests were used as appropriate to assess continuous variables for significant differences between groups. For numerical variables, an independent-samples t-testt-test (normally distributed data) was used to compare values between groups. Dichotomous variables were assessed using a chi-squared test or a Fisher’s exact test (if five or less in one cell) between group comparisons. Kaplan-Meier methodology was used to investigate 30 day survival after hip fracture and log-rank (Mantel-Cox) was used to compare survival between COVID-19 positive patients to those without a positive diagnosis. Cox regression analysis was used to assess the independent association of COVID-19 status and 30 day mortality. Logistic regression analyses were used to assess the independence of predictors associated with a COVID-19 positive patient with a hip fracture. Variables with statistical significance at a p-value or a trend towards significance (p < 0.100) on univariate analyses were included in the multivariate model. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis was used to identify a threshold value in the scalar variables that were identified as predictors associated with a COVID-19 positive patient. The area under the ROC curve (AUC) ranges from 0.5, indicating a test with no accuracy in distinguishing whether a patient is COVID-19 positive, to 1.0 where the test is perfectly accurate identifying all COVID-19 positive patients. The threshold value was defined as the point at which the sensitivity and specificity were maximal in predicting a COVID-19 positive patient.20 A p-value < 0.05 was defined as statistically significant.
body.title: Results
Primary aim: the independent influence of COVID-19 on patient mortality
body.p: There were 27 patients in total that were proven to be infected with COVID-19 in the study cohort, of which seven demonstrated symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 at admission, but only six were swab-positive at admission, with the remaining patient becoming positive on the second swab. The remaining 20 patients did not have symptoms suggestive of infection on admission but later became swab-positive during their hospital stay, of which 11 tested positive before 14 days and nine tested positive after 14 days from admission. There were 33 patient deaths in the first 30 days following hip fracture, of which nine were directly related to COVID-19. Patients that were COVID-19 positive at any stage had a significantly lower rate of survival when compared to those without a proven COVID-19 infection (64.5%, 95% confidence intervals (CI) 45.7 to 83.3 vs 91.5%, 95% CI 88.2 to 94.8; p < 0.001, log-rank test, Figure 1). When patients who had COVID-19 on admission were compared to those who were diagnosed positive during admission, there was no difference in survival, and moreover survival for both groups remained significantly lower than for patients without COVID-19 (Figure 2).

caption.title: Kaplan-Meier curve for 30 day survival according to whether a patient was COVID-19 negative (grey) or COVID-19 positive (black) - 91.5% vs 64.5% at 30 days; p < 0.001, log-rank test.

Kaplan-Meier curve for 30 day survival according to whether a patient was COVID-19 negative (grey) or COVID-19 positive on admission (black) or were positive during their admission (black dashed line); p < 0.001, log-rank.

body.p: Univariate analysis demonstrated that factors significantly associated with 30 day mortality were older age (mean increase of 5.7 years; 95% CI 1.9 to 9.4; p = 0.004), male sex (odds ratio (OR) 2.67; 95% CI 1.29 to 5.55; p = 0.007), care/nursing home residence (OR 2.4; 95% CI 1.07 to 5.38; p = 0.030), a higher Nottingham Hip Fracture Score (OR 1.1; 95% CI 0.5 to 1.7; p < 0.001), increasing ASA grade (p < 0.001), non-operativenonoperative management (OR 9.75; 95% CI 3.03 to 31.3; p < 0.001), and a positive COVID-19 status (OR 5.54; 95% CI 2.25 to 13.67; p < 0.001) (Table I). The influence of non-operativenonoperative management was thought to be a secondary marker of risk of death and was not included in the regression models. The Nottingham Hip Fracture Score includes age, sex, and place of residence and was therefore not independent of these factors, and the same was found with the ASA grade due to high multicollinearity. Three separate Cox regression models were used to assess the independent association of COVID-19 with mortality risk when adjusting for 1) age, sex, and place of residence, 2) Nottingham Hip Fracture Score, and 3) the patient’s ASA grade(Table III). When adjusting for these confounding variables COVID-19 positive status was independently associated with a higher 30 day mortality risk (Table III).

caption.title: Cox regression models of 30 day survival according to COVID-19 status.

body.title: Secondary aim:1) predictors at time of presentation associated with having or developing COVID-19
body.p: The 27 patients who tested positive for COVID-19 either at admission (n = 6) or subsequently became positive during their admission (n = 21) were assessed on univariate analysis and male sex (OR 2.32; 95% CI 1.05 to 5.13; p = 0.034) and a lower platelet count (54.2; 95% CI 15.3 to 93.0; p = 0.006) were found to be associated with a positive COVID-19 diagnosis (Table IV). Male sex and low platelet count were independently associated with a positive COVID-19 diagnosis when adjusting for one another (Table V). ROC curve analysis illustrated that platelet count at time of presentation was a reliable predictor of COVID-19 status with an AUC of 68% (95% CI 58 to 77; p = 0.002) and a threshold value in the platelet count of 217 × 109/l which had a sensitivity and specificity of 63% (Figure 3). This threshold value was then entered into the regression model with male sex, and a platelet count of < 217×109/l remained a significant independent predictor associated with an increased risk of the patient being COVID-19 positive at presentation or at any time in the study period (Table VI).

caption.title: Patient demographics, Nottingham Hip Fracture Score, presentation blood results, residence, place of injury, study centre, and management according to COVID status.

Receiver operating characteristic curve for platelet count as a predictor of COVID-19. Area under the curve 67.8% (95% confidence interval 58.3 to 77.3; p = 0.002), with a threshold platelet count value of 217 × 109/ l.

body.title: Secondary aim: 2) social lockdown and influence on the epidemiology of hip fracture
body.p: A similar number of patients presented with a hip fracture in the 23 days prior to social lockdown (n = 160) and in the 23 days following lockdown (n = 157). There were no significant (all p ≥ 0.130) differences found in patient demographics (age and sex), residence, place of injury, Nottingham Hip Fracture Score, time to surgery, ASA grade, or management pre- or post-lockdown (Table II). However, there were significantly fewer general anaesthetics preformed after lockdown (OR 0.20, 95% CI (0.10 to 0.43); p < 0.001) and there was a shorter length of stay (11.3, (SD 7.5) days vs 7.8 days (SD 4.6); p < 0.001). In addition, there was also a trend (OR 2.74, 95% CI 0.83 to 9.09; p = 0.102) towards a greater rate of non-operativenonoperative management post-lockdown. Of the 14 patients managed non-operatively, two were positive for COVID-19, and a further three patients were clinically suspected of having COVID-19 without a positive laboratory diagnosis.
body.title: Discussion
body.p: This multicentre study has demonstrated that a swab positive diagnosis of COVID-19 either at admission or during admission for a hip fracture was associated with an increased 30 day mortality, which was four times that of hip fractures patients without COVID-19. The increased mortality rate associated with a COVID-19 diagnosis was independent of age, sex, residence, Nottingham Hip Fracture Score and ASA grade. The mortality rate was higher than that reported in a UK study of adult hospitalized patients (all categories) with COVID-19 (mortality 26%), although in that study the median age was 73 years (interquartile range (IQR) 58 to 82), and reporting time was variable (minimum two weeks).5 Male sex and lower platelet count at admission were independently associated with a COVID-19 positive diagnosis in patients with a hip fracture in the current study, with a platelet count of < 217×109/l 63% sensitive and specific. The incidence of hip fractures was not affected by social lockdown during the study period. However, there was an increased rate of spinal anaesthesia and a shorter length of acute hospital stay after social lockdown.

The results of this study, which used data from a healthcare system in which hip fracture care is delivered consistently and in accordance with a set of nationally agreed evidence-based care standards,21 demonstrated an increased 30 day mortality in patients with COVID-19 infection compared with those without and was independent of other confounding factors assessed. These findings are consistent with those reported in other European healthcare systems.7,22 However, the current study is the largest to date and the first to use survivorship methodology to quantify the risk and adjust for confounding variables. A diagnosis of COVID-19 was also demonstrated to be independent of the Nottingham Hip Fracture Score that may now require amending in the context of COVID-19 and the association with postoperative mortality.8 Extrapolation of the survival curve for patients who experience the onset of COVID-19 during admission for a period longer than the current 30 day follow-up may demonstrate patterns of early mortality consistent with that of patients who had active infection with a positive diagnosis at admission. This may indicate 60- and 90 day follow-up may be needed to assess the full effect of COVID-19 on patient mortality.

Some authors have advocated the option of non-operativenonoperative management for hip fracture patients with COVID-19.23 Any decision to operate should be made on a case-by-case basis, however the authors would suggest that the evidence from this study and from the existing literature does not support routine deviation from operative management. Although the 30 day mortality risk is increased in patients with COVID-19, only two of the 27 patients with a positive diagnosis were managed non-operatively in view of significant respiratory compromise, and both subsequently died at day two and day 11 of their admission. While the mortality for patients with COVID-19 was higher than those without, nearly two-thirds of these patients were alive one month following their admission. Indeed surgical management has been demonstrated to aid the respiratory function and recovery in hip fracture patients affected by COVID-19.22

The majority (n = 20/27; 74%) of patients in our study with COVID-19 became symptomatic and tested positive for COVID-19 after acute hip fracture admission, of whom six patients tested positive 14 days from admission. COVID-19 is associated with an asymptomatic incubation period reported to be most frequently between five and eight days24 and patients (especially elderly and frail patients who are at greatest risk of hip fracture) may remain asymptomatic or demonstrate atypical or non-specific features such as delirium, during which period they can be considered asymptomatic carriers and at risk of infecting patients or staff.6,25-27 Importantly, patients who were reported as having the onset of symptoms and a positive COVID-19 test result beyond 14 days into admission for hip fracture may have contracted the infection as an inpatient, which raises theconcern of patient-to-patient and staff-to-patient spread in the hospital setting.6,24 These findings may support the development of strategies and pathways to mitigate against in-hospital spread of COVID-19, such as managing hip fracture patients in small protected ‘cohorts’ or in ‘ring-fenced’ areas, ensuring minimum patient movement, and introducing repeated testing throughout the duration of the hospital admission. Patient pathways have been suggested by previous authors to prevent cross-infection between patients.6,22

A major limitation of the current study is the reliance on positive nasopharyngeal swabs for SARS-CoV-2 RNA to assign the diagnosis of COVID-19 to patients with acute hip fractures. The sensitivity of the reverse transcriptase PCR is not 100%, with a systematic review suggesting it could be as low as 71% and one study reporting a false negative rate of 29%.28,29 The sensitivity also varies according to the anatomical site (sputum 72%, nasal swab 63%, and throat swab 32%) and the stage of the disease.30,31 As there is no clear standard to assigning the diagnosis of COVID-19, both clinical suspicion and current swab testing may be the best way to identify patients at risk of being infected with SARS-CoV-2. The pre-test probability of a patient having COVID-19 directly affects the chance of a patient having a false negative test for SARS-CoV-2. For example, a cohort of 100 patients with a test sensitivity of 71% and specificity of 95%28,29 and a background infection risk of 8.5% (identified in the current study) would result in three patients with COVID-19 being tested negative, whereas if there is a 50% clinical risk of a patient having the infection 15 patients with COVID-19 would be missed with a false negative test.

Clinical practicalities may preclude the introduction of rigorous isolation or ‘cohorting’ strategies for all hip fracture patients, but clinical features that may be predictive of COVID-19 infection may assist the logistical management of hip fracture pathways in hospital. The assessment of perioperative risk could help guide clinical decision-making and discussion with patients, staff, and carers, and to stratify the risk of cross-infection during the hospital admission. The current study demonstrates a clear association between lower platelet count on admission laboratory testing and a positive COVID-19 infection. The sensitivity and specificity were 63% using a threshold level of 217 × 109/l. While more information is required to delineate the nature of the causative relationship between lower admission platelet count and COVID-19 infection, it is nonetheless a potential predictor to be used in the clinical setting. This finding is consistent with the known pathophysiological processes of COVID-19 in which a relative thrombocytopenia is reported as a clinical feature and a risk factor for increased morbidity and mortality in patients infected with SARS-CoV-2.15,32

At the time of data collection there was no specific SARS-CoV-2 swab testing strategy with regard to indication or timing of testing was in place, which was consistent within all participating hospitals. Consistency of approach to testing for active COVID-19 infection, such as routine for all patients on admission, or prior to discharge from the acute care setting, may provide a more reliable and predictable context within which to interpret results and guide inpatient cohorting and discharge planning decisions.

The number of patients admitted with a hip fracture during the 23 days prior to lockdown and 23 days following lockdown were nearly identical and this is consistent with other authors that have found no change in the rate of these fractures during the COVID-19 pandemic.3,4,33 These data strongly suggest that the pathways and clinical resources for the management of these frail patients should be preserved and prioritized in future lockdowns and pandemics. The number of spinal anaesthetics increased significantly after the lockdown period, which likely reflects the recognized increased risk of aerosol-transmitted infection associated with an airway intubation.34 The length of acute hospital stay was significantly shorter post-lockdown and may reflect an increased focus on early discharge from hospital to avoid potential exposure to infection, or it may be that there are more resources available due to a significant reduction in the polytrauma workload.3,4

The large sample size and multicentre nature of the data collection is a strength of the current study. The authors appreciate that there is variation with respect to COVID-19 infection and hip fracture incidence between regions, as well as with respect to testing strategies, social distancing policies, and enforced lockdown measures. More evidence from a larger sample size(Table VII) (gathered from a larger number of centres and units, with a greater geographical spread providing greater generalizability with respect to public health measures, COVID-19 prevalence, and infection control strategies) is required for a better understanding of hip fracture incidence, epidemiology, patterns of COVID-19 infection, and the effects of variation in community infection rates and disease control strategies. More information is needed to identify factors that may be predictive of COVID-19 infection and early mortality in order to guide clinical decision-making, as well as to assess the impact and mitigate the disruption of the viral pandemic on hip fracture services.

td.code: While running Apply house rules, the table should get set as per the customer style and configuration.

body.p: In conclusion, a diagnosis of COVID-19 was independently associated with an increased 30 day mortality rate for patients with a hip fracture. Most patients that had a hip fracture and were COVID-19 positive were asymptomatic at presentation, which suggests standardized patient pathways may be needed to prevent cross-infection. Platelet count(Table VIII) at admission was found to be an indicator of risk of COVID-19 status and could be used as part of risk assessment pathways. There was no change in the rate or epidemiology of hip fracture patients pre- and post-social lockdown and clinical resources for the management of these frail patients should be prioritized in future lockdowns and pandemics.

caption.title: Logistic regression analysis was used to adjust for confounding between the groups to assess the independent association with COVID-19.
